bottle - Pours hazy gold with a lingering white head and good lacing. It smells of assertive pine accented hops, which I really like. The flavor is definitely led by the hops. Its earthy and piney with ample bitterness. Theres something slightly lacking about the body, but overall its an enjoyable, full-flavored, imminently sessionable IPA.

Bottle. Cloudy golden color. Aroma is dank wet hops, cantaloupe, orange peel, very floral and fragrant. The flavor lives up to the aroma sales pitch. Full of dank hop flavor, cantaloupe, grapefruit, orange peel. Nice bitter finish but full of flavors. This goes down waaaaay too easy. Now to go get a 6-pack.
Love this gem of a "sessionable" IPA. It's refreshing and full of flavor. However, sessionable beer should be sessionabley priced.
draft at stone tap takeover, congrats on keeping up with the times stone. Crushable, hoppy, lightly bitter, maltless ipa. Goldmine.

355ml bottle into a shaker glass; served cold.

Aroma: Bright lemon zest! Basically all lemon with just a little bit of grapefruit. Very bright.

Appearance: Slightly hazy, bright yellow body. Foamy, creamy, white head. Nice lacing.

Taste: Lemon and grapefruit again. Lightly bitter. Flavor really pops, its very bright, but full.

Palate: Light+ body, decent length on finish. Ends on gentle bitterness.

Overall: A fine beer indeed; full-flavored without being overpowering. Tasty and delicious.
Aroma of citrus and pine with fruity, parfumy undertones. Pours golden yellow with white head. Citrusy taste, pine notes, very light body. Overall decent ipa.

Bottle. Bout time I got around to this. Pours a nice clean gold with a medium head and hoppy aromas of tropical and citrus fruit. Flavor is crisp and clean with a very nice guest of that hops presence from the nose. Darn fine and the best session ipa I have had.
user_location: The Wet Side of a Dry Town, Pennsylvania, USA

text: Hop assault in the nose from the first sniff ands all through the enjoyment in the glass. Cloudy gold appearance, Mouthfeel that starts full but does dissipate as would be expected in a session IPA. Aftertaste is all hop residual with lemon peel. A great take on a session with balls.

Bottle. Being a lighter beer I thought my wife would enjoy sharing this beer with me. Im glad that at her 1st sip she said it still had too much flavor for her. (She is banished back to her Lite beers and Blue Moon) Golden yellow with moderate head. Good citrus hop aroma. Sweet orange barley malt and moderately bitter grapefruit flavor. Body a bit light. Very sessionable.

(Bottle) Cloudy orange body with a small, disappearing off-white head. Powerful hop aroma of orange and grapefruit peel, resin, lemongrass, with other fruity and floral notes. Medium body, soft. Flavor is strongly bitter, acidic, some underlying sweetness (honey) but mostly masked by bitterness and the dry, slightly floral finish. Good session IPA, which is what they are going for.
Tap. Hazy golden pour with a good head. Citrus, banana, orange, floral, spice. Light and crisp yet with flavor and character. Nice

Poured into a pint glass, its a nice golden color with a good head and nice lacing. Aroma of grapefruit. Strong citrus/grapefruit flavor with a nice bitter finish. Lighter in body than their standard IPA. Nice summer brew.

Pours a half finger of head on a hazy lighter straw colored body.
The aroma is bright and tropical: pineapple, mango and grapefruit. Wonderful.
The taste is big lemon bitterness upfront, then tones down towards the end. The bitter dominates though.
The texture is crisp and fizzy with moderate carbonation.
Quite enjoyable.

Bottle. Pours a hazy light yellow with a white head that dissipates quickly to the edges. Aroma has a musty onion note with some pine and a bit of underlying dankness. Flavor has grass and onion with some earthy grain for the backbone.
UPDATED: JUN 11, 2014 Golden orange pour with a huge white head and lots of lacing. Aroma of citeus and pine. Taste follows with moderate bitterness. Goes down easy.
Bottle from Hazels beverage world. Amber color, white head. Bitter taste with hops, grapefruit, mango, pine and resin. Bitter finish with grapefruit, pine and mango. Excellent session IPA.

Golden color with a bit of white head. Smell is dank, grapefruit, orange, a little graininess. Taste is very dank hop, a mild bitter, a light honey sweetness. A good taste, great drinking beer. Slick mouthfeel, dry, light carbonation. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
Its strange to drink a stone beer that doesnt punch you in the face, but this is one that offers balance and a good amount of flavor. Tropical and citrus hops.

Pours hazy light amber color, with a medium head. Nose of citrus and grass, flavors likewise but giving way quickly to a nice malt balance, though light in body. Good result for a relatively low-alcohol brew, could drink a bunch of this at the lake on a hot day.

Appearance is a hazy light golden, with a minimal foam cap. Aroma is an amazing burst of fresh cut grass, pine, and grapefruit. Taste is very light malt that goes straight to an almost harsh hop bitterness, with tones of grass and pine. Mouthfeel is thin and light with moderate carbonation. Finishes with a harsh bitterness that leaves a foot like taste on the tongue. Its a session IPA alright, totally missing the malt character needed to balance this beer out

Bottle. 
Clear golden color, with a steady white head. 
Hoppy nose, with notes of grapes and flowers. 
Very hoppy taste, with a long bitter finish. Pretty clean taste. 
Average carbonation, medium body.
12oz bottle. Color of a Golden Ale, white foam. Aromas of citrus hops & pineapple. Flavor of dank, some pine. High Alphas. Very thin body. Hops dominate the character. Overly sessionable. (4082)

Refrigerated 12 oz. brown bottle poured into a snifter. Pours hazy golden with medium white head. Aroma is grapefruit, medium body, medium carbonation, and medium small bubble lacing. Taste is light tropical fruit, herbal hops,and light bitter finish. Good session IPA, but lacks favor of some of the best IPAs.

Appearance was clear gold with white lasting creamy 1 finger head, rings of lacing. Aromas are citrus fruits, pine, earthy spicy hops with slight pale sweetness. Taste are soft pale malt upfront then all grapefruit, lemon, lime, tangerine with earthy pine backing. Palate was soft creamy smooth CO2 with light body, then lasting fruity piney finish. An easy sessionable IPA to throw back.

This took me absolutely by surprise. I was expecting a tasty brew, but this is really, really outlandish considering how low the abv is.

This is resolutely fantastic. It is very dry, it reminds me of Ports Hop Tide, but mellower and more balances. Very little malt backbone in this, huge hops, citrusy,  piney, resiny, dank and earthy... not sweet at all. Amazing on the nose, and loks yellow. On the mouth, crisp, dry, very bitter. And immensely flavorful. No other beer this this abv has this much character and stature. 

The best session IPA I have ever had, bar none. And one of Stones best beers too, I dare say. I like this better than their regular IPA, than Ruination. Enjoy by still takes the cake for me from their regular IPA fleet, but this is damn close. I would love to see them do a bigger version of this: a very dry, low malt base resiny IPA. 

It is a world class IPA in my opinion, for those of us who like our IPAs dry, piney and bitter. Amazing stuff.

Pours a gold light amber with nice pillow soft head. Aroma is citrucy tangerines and a hint of lime and cat litter box.. Taste is like lemon bitter upfront then a sweet caramel malt takes over then the lemon bitterness comes back for the finish with grapefruit on the tongue.  Nice lacing down the glass. Its pretty good but not great. On a hot day ya ok.

Slightly hazy golden coloured body with a thin, single centimetre tall white head. Aroma of super pungent hops with citrus and grapefruit by far the strongest around, with very little malt (expected) and no sweetness at all. Light-bodied; Pungent flavour of citrus, tropical fruits (pineapple, guava, passionfruit) and resin up front with no malt backbone at all and a touch of sweetness from the tropical fruits, but nothing really to grab hold of. Aftertaste shows the hops of course, but with nothing else, its sort of a lost effort. Overall, a decent session-based IPA at best, but the hops from dry hopping are evident in the aroma, but thats about it, there isnt much in the flavour or the finish to warrant another one of these. If you were going to have some beer for around the same alcohol, drink a single stone ipa not two of these, otherwise youll be disappointed. I sampled this twelve ounce bottle purchased from Whole Foods in Falls Church (Tysons Corner), Virginia on 13-March-2014 for US$2.49 sampled at home in Washington on 02-June-2014.

Bottle at home in Salisbury - picked up at De Cicco, Armonk. Pours crystal clear yellow-gold with a nice, frothy white head. God damn, this beer smells outrageously good. Just bursting with fresh, juicy citrus and dank piss. Light sweet flavor with minimal bitterness and a hop character that absolutely sings. Lots of pithy, clean grapefruit, some cat pee, just enough pale malt sugars to support the hops. Light bodied with fine to average carbonation. Super clean and fresh to finish, lightly crisp, with hints of oily resins, more pithy grapefruit, mild lemon amd tangerine, pee, some vague pine needles. Stunning. I could drink a lot of this beer.

Another home run from Stone. Drinking Go to Dry Hopped with Amarillo! Aroma is awesome!

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Applaud idea to make a relatively low alcohol ipa but this just does not taste good enough to me to justify drinking another. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

(Bottle). The aroma is a burst of pine with some grapefruit. Overly filter complexion with thin head but good glass lacing. The flavor has serious IBU with pine. A bit one sided. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

On tap at Freshcraft. Pour is clear golden with a frothy white head and great lacing. Big hoppy, piney, something orangey, fruity, weedy, and biscuity aroma. Taste is heavy weed, ganja, grapefruit peel, oranges, pine needles, straw, and dough with a big bitter finish. Light body with medium carbonation. Clean body and super hoppy. Great session IPA.
UPDATED: JUN 18, 2014 A beer that is aptly named if you are looking to have a session. But, given the excellence of its siblings at Stone, it is one more likely to be passed by (or through).

aroma was very weak,slight citrus..the appearance was somewhat opaque and hazy.the taste was very bitter and overwhelmed the malts,which were nice tasting.very unbalanced.one the palate was light to medium and average at best.i was disappointed in this beer,since it had high ratings.

12 ounce bottle - $1.99 at Total Wine & More in Kennesaw, Georgia.

Appearance: Pours a hazed, yellow-toned body with a medium-small, white head.

Smell: Citric fruitiness, a little sliver of melon. Pine, florals. Maltiness is modest, just a little lightly toasted grain.

Taste: Nominal malts with a little grainy dough kick and a minimal, initial sweetness. Citrus, with a tropical fruity bent to it and steely pine. Medium-plus bitterness. Growing acidity as the lingering, accumulating bitterness which develops into the drying, citric, grassy finish.

Mouthfeel: Medium-light body. Medium plus carbonation.

Overall: Black, White and Session IPAs. Where do IPAs go from here?

Wheres the love for this beer? I thought it was fantastic. Tasted like Enjoy by to me, but more mild and much less alcohol obviously. Pours a golden color and fairly clear. Aroma was dank and had mixed in pine and citrus. Taste follows the nose. Light body, highly drinkable, and very tasty. If youre an IPA fan then you cant go wrong here, plus its very easily found all over.

UPDATED: AUG 27, 2015 Pale golden amber with a fluffy off-white head and plenty of lacing. Aroma of pine, herb, grain, and tropical fruit. Solid bitterness dominates over some mild grainy and fruity flavors. Light bodied, slick, softly carbonated.

Pours clear golden-amber with a 1-finger white head. Aroma of citrusy hops and citrus peel, stronger than I expected. Medium body with a light oily thickness. Flavor is all hops- citrusy and resiny. Flavor is surprisingly strong for a low ABV beer.

On tap at Rustico. Pours a clear hay colored yellow with fading white head and lacing. Aroma is mild; bitterness, yeast, lemon citrus. Flavor is bitter, with notes of wheat grass and lemon. Overall unbalanced to me.
Nice, light session IPA. Pours golden with medium head. Slight piney hops. Good stuff here

Draft. Earthy dirty hops up front on the nose. Pour is a slightly hazy golden color with a large white head. Taste is immediately danky with a solid malt backbone. First IPA Ive had with such massive malt support. Still has a drying hoppy finish. Very good but just short of session able due to the big malt factor.
bottle shared with josh hakes drive at club w. hazy light orange pour with thin white head, aroa is hoppy medicine, and hospital, taste is similar but metallic, and smooth, good

12oz bottle. Clear light amber body with small white head. Aroma is medium sweet, pine, some grapefruit, light lemon. Taste is medium sweet, pine/grapefruit, light lemon. Light body, light acidity. Quite drinkable (I should know, given how many of them I drank this past weekend).

Pale straw color pour. Light white head. Big tropical fruit and citrus hop aroma. Very light body. Tropical hop flavors still very strong. No malt flavor. Not overly bitter or dry finish. 

---Rated via iPhone

Draft at Lucys Restaurant in Richmond with friends The IPA poured a cloudy gold color with a white head and lacing. It is good beer for lunch. The aroma was of grapefruit and pine resin. The complex ale had a bitterness that hung on the tongue. The ale had a medium body and average carbonation. The finish was dry with lingering bitterness of grapefruit. This is an IPA with a lower ABV that could be consumed at any time.

Golden color out of the bottle with a sticky white head. Big pine and grapefruit citrus hop nose. Bitter red grapefruit and sharp pine flavors with a pinching hop resin finish. It is really like hop juice. Finish is a bit raw, but if you like hops this is that.
Hazy golden yellow with large white head. Big danky, cat pee, hop aroma. Same huge hop flavor up front, fairly thin, decent bitterness in the finish. Very crisp and refreshing.

Bottle.  Bottled on:  04/22/14 (I think).  Pours a pale amber with a one finger-thick off-white head.  The pungent aroma features tons of grapefruits, apricots, peaches, zesty citrus rinds, resiny pine, weed, and some caramel.  Goes down thin to medium-bodied, crisp, and pretty refreshing.  Semi-sweet upfront taste-wise with a little caramel and a sizable biscuity presence.  Dried apricots, white peaches, and a hint of vanilla follow.  Grapefruits and zesty citrus rinds finish things off with a lingering dryness.  Resiny.  Very flavorful for such a low ABV.  Impressive.

bottle. golden with two finger head. light body. ridiculous hop flavor with only medium hop bitterness. lots of pine and citrus. theres much more hop flavor here than most imperial ipas. its amazing that theyve done this in a 4.5% beer.
Bottle->SA. Hazy pale yellow with small white head. A: lots of hops, pine and citrus. T: bitter hops, musky. Quite good.

Hazy golden color; Light to medium body; Aroma of pine/resin hops, floral, & citrus; Flavor of malt, pine hops, and citrus (notably grapefruit); Finish is bitter; Nicely balanced; Very solid session IPA.
Slightly hazy copper color. Nice light pine hop smell. Light smooth easy drinking IPA light hop bitter but still crisp and light. Great summer beer for Ipa Drinkers.

12oz bottle. Pours a golden color with generous off-white head. Intense citrusy aroma with just a bit of pine. Aggressive bitter hop flavor that one would expect from a Stone beer. This tastes nothing like a 4.5% beer. Smooth lingering bitter finish. This beer is pure hops. Outstanding.

Drafy at Moriartys. Hazy gold pour. Large frothy head. Full, bitter, pungent hop notes. Green resin spice. Grapefruit pith imperial. Lemon pips. Lime zest. Sweet citrus straw. Big grassy IPA. Pretty damn good for a session beer. Loads of hop flavor. Great stuff!!!
Really good and balanced. Nice aroma and better flavor. Dtone knows how to make an ipa.

12oz bottle. Pours a nearly clear, pale yellow with a one finger, white head that thins to a film that still provides decent lacing. Aroma has some nice pine, resin, tropical fruit, and bread notes. Slight grass/herbal qualities as well. Taste is balanced with some continuing grass/herbal/earthy points. Resin, pine, and bread as well with a short aftertaste. Low-medium body with a medium carbonation. Lighter texture in the mouth without being watery. Overall a really nice session IPA. Pine resin, herbal notes combined with a short aftertaste makes this very refreshing. Yum!

A golden body with a thin white head that had mild retention. Aroma had a nice biscuit malt presence upfront. A nice slightly pine hop note. floral and talcum powder balanced it out. Complex with out being over powering. Flavor had a mild malt flavor, hops were a nice mix of pine and tropical fruit. Well balanced. Finish was light and slightly dry. Only disappointment was the appearance. It seemed too pale.
Pale gold color, citrus aroma, citrus hop profile that isnt overtly bitter, smooth drinking, sessionable.

Nose is dry , dank and biscuity. Flavour is a great dry bitterness straight through to the finish . Great session IPA 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

A real achievement to pack this much flavour and definition into a 4.5% beer. Clean as a whistle with grassy hops, big herbal nose and stone dry fruits to finish. Does tail somewhat but hey at these abv levels all is forgiven,
12 oz. bottle. Poured golden with thin head. Nice lacing. Aroma of grass, tangerine, orange, pine needles. Flavor is piney with citrus. Good hop bite. Great session IPA.

A great session IPA. Aroma was big and full of hops. Hot with grapefruit and pine. Pour was a nice clear light gold with a one finger white head. Taste was strongly bitter and hoppy. Pine and earth with notes of dry grass and a bitter hoppy grapefruit finish. So deliciously bitter. A little astringent. Nice strong biting carbonation. Excellent
user_location: Moon Twp, suburb of Pittsburgh, Pennsylvania, USA

text:
From bottle. Pours semi clear straw yellow. Smaller head with big bubbles, some lacing. Smells of grapefruit, spruce, sweet pine. Like walking through a forest. Taste us intensely hoppy. Bold bitter citrus fruit right off the bat, finish is bitter hop with lemon undertone. Creamy texture. Nice but powerful. Cannot believe this is a Session beer, only 4.5% alcohol

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Keg at Stone Brewing, San Diego Flughafen, 22/04/14.
Clear golden with a well appointed white covering that stays for the show.
Nose is citric sherbets, pine, straw, grapefruit, orange pith.
Taste comprises punchy hops, pine, grapefruit, pithy orange, light mango, grass.
Medium bodied, fine carbonation, semi drying clos.
Solid well constructed session IPA.
user_location: Hazlemere, the lower Xhitlerns, Buckinghamshire, ENGLAND

text:
Bottle from Berts
Pours a slightly hazy light golden color with a huge bubbly beige head that persists forever before sticking lots of lace on the sides. Dank resinous earthy pine fills my nostrils. Bits of green onion and a hint of bread round things out in the aroma. The flavor is moderate earthy spicy pine hop flavor with a thin light bready malt beneath. Light body with a moderate level of carbonation and a thin somewhat watery mouthfeel. This one has light and refreshing down, I could probably drink a ton of these on a warm summers day. Unfortunately, I dont think I would, the body for me is too light and I hate to say this, but I want more maltiness. Nothing horrible or flawed here, but this one is not for me.
Very fruity and piney!! With an excellent smack of hops definitely a beer you can enjoy all day long

On tap at The Olympic Tavern, pours a clear gold with a thin white head, the aroma was pretty nuts, tons of tropical fruit and citrus pour out of the glass, the flavor has a huge hop front end with a thinner finish and light mouthfeel, crushable for the summer time.
Nice citrus aroma coming from this pale yellow pour. Super bitter taste and finish. Smooth on the palate, surprisingly good for such a low ABV. Nicely done !

Beautiful clear sunny yellow, white head. Aroma is fresh, juicy citrus, lychee, and faint juniper. Taste is bitter citrus rind, lychee, and resin, and a little salty. Finish is bitter. Palate is clean, carbonation a little subdued, which is nice. Lacing is light. I do wish this tasted as good as it smells and looks...

Very nice in the glass. Clean and refined appearance. Golden yellow body with bright white one-finger lasting head. 
Aroma is fairly bold and remarkable. Onion, skunk, grass & florals dominate. The savoury notes are balanced by the contributing fruit notes of mango and peach.
Taste is sweet citrus, evolving Mango and more skunk, herbal growth before a clean spicy bitter-finish.
The palate is a revelation. I really expected (due to my session-IPA immaturity) that this would be skeletal and disappointing. Far from it. It is creamy and fulfilling.
Nice go to beer except the price 12/6 pack. Not goto. Full of grapefruit. A bit pale clear and fizzy yellow.

On tap at the Yard House, Houston. It pours a clear golden body and a minimal sized white head. The aroma is on the hoppy side, with lots of pine cones and a solid shot of peaches. Some grass and pale malts. Theres a nice bitterness in the mouth, with the same piney and lightly peachy touch. Its dry and more or less full bodied and with a nice carbonation. Lasting bitter and fruity finish. A quenching and tasteful session IPA. Just like they should be. 140513

Beer pours lightly cloudy honey golden color with a retained egg white head. Hop aroma is very pronounced with big citrus and resin aromas. Not really any malt balance in the aroma. Taste is straight forwardly bitter. This is an unbalanced brew, but in the best sense of the word. A hop heads delight!
Draft - Fresh grapefruit and leafy pine. Pale gold with a thin white head. Bright grapefruit and lemon with a quick hit of bitterness. A great, refreshing clean IPA.

Draft. Pours a clear light yellow with white head. Excellent aroma, tons of hops, really pine driven. Taste is great as well. Wow, very intense hops, bitter pine. Like it a lot, will buy in quantity this summer for session time.
This has quite a solid hop presence for being relatively light in alcohol. But it doesnt really taste like a session IPA, more of a regular IPA. Good though.
Bottle. Orange malt and spruce/grapefruit peel (cat-pee) aroma. Golden yellow with moderate head. Sweet orange barley malt and moderately bitter grapefruit peel flavor. Body a bit light. Very nice.

UPDATED: AUG 21, 2015 Draught @ Toronado, San Francisco, CA

Pours golden orange with a smooth head. Aroma of fresh citrusy hops, grass, lemon and caramel. Taste is smooth, hoppy and citrusy with some refreshing lemony notes. Finish is bitter, hoppy and malty with some citrusy notes. Quite refreshing and tasty session IPA. Re-rated at Stone tap room. Much more fresh and juicy. Tasty.
Draft at Olympic. From notes. Meh, decent IPA but nothing too special. Piney.
Bottle from Specs. Pours a golden yellow with a medium white head. The aromas are grass, citrus. The mouthfeel is dry, bitter and a little watery. This is an excellent session beer. Cheers!

Bottle. Bright orange golden colored with a solid layer of sudsy foam and bubbles. Aroma is a mix of resiny hops, pine, cannabis and citrus. The taste starts out with a blend of tropical fruit, grassy hops bitterness and grapefruit with a bit of pine resin and toasted grain toward the end. The body is slightly creamy with medium carbonation and a clean, bitter finish. About as hoppy and flavorful as you can expect a Session IPA to be.
This is really nice. Pale golden yellow in the glass with a thin white head. Very potent floral, fruit, and citrus hop aroma. Medium body, reasonable bitterness but not overwhelming.

Bottle.

Head is initially average sized, frothy, white, mostly diminishing.
Body is medium yellow.

Aroma is lightly malty (toasted grain), lightly to moderately hoppy (resin, grapefruit), lightly yeasty (dough), with a note of ginger candies, light note of plastic.

Flavor is lightly to moderately sweet, lightly to moderately acidic, lightly to moderately bitter.
Finish is lightly sweet, lightly to moderately acidic, moderately to heavily bitter.

Light to medium body, watery texture, lively carbonation.

Very simple, crude, and dull. Stone, like New Belgium, just doesnt seem to care anymore.
Bottle. Similar to some other session IPAs, very piney all around. Yellow, a little cloudy, with a tall foamy head. Long coating finish. All around okay, but not overly special.

Location: This rating is a combination of my notes from a draft rating as a guest tap at Gaslight (3/22/14) and a 12 oz bottle from Buy Rite (5/9/14, enjoy by 7/24/14)


Aroma: The aroma is clean hops, lots of pine, some mild citrus notes

Appearance: It pours a clear orange color with a small froth of white head and medium lace

Flavor: The flavor is lightly sweet, with a good amount of hops, clean and bitter

Palate:The body is light-medium, very easy drinking, clean, smooth, and dry on the finish 

Overall Impression: 
This is pretty much exactly what you want from a low ABV IPA. It is clean and very hoppy, it isnt watery at all, and it has a dry finish. What else would one want in this style? Additional note, I rated the bottle version better than I did the tap version, this rating is the higher score overall

Cloudy golden pour with eighth inch of white head. Strong hoppy aroma, super bright citrus on the verge of chemical it was so strong and concentrated, lacking complexity though. Lively carbonation, mouthfeel moderately thick, finishes crisp. Taste is more of the same - bright citrus and floral hops, nutty malt, salty slightly bitter finish. Very well balanced and full bodied for a session.

Blind tasting with the S&G Tasting group. THX to Mathieu87!
Only wrote down some small words and the score.
Although most people at the tasting didnt like this one, I enjoyed it quite a lot. Quite fruity nose and quite dry taste. OKé

Well here we go. The new craft beer trend - the Session IPA. Feel like Ill be rating quite a few of these coming up soon. This is basically the Stone IPA minus the steroids. AkA its great! Drink up.

Chosen to grace my first flight at Stones Liberty Station outlet in San Diego on 17th March 2014 (the light flight as I called it). Most enjoyable. Light golden body with a white covering: didnt look like it carried as many hops as it does. Grapefruit laden citrus aroma and taste with the malts playing second fiddle throughout the tasting: this is all about the noble hop. Refreshing, bitter and thought provoking. I liked the fact it was only 4.5% ABV too, the heavy hitters were to come on flights 2 and 3!

12oz bottle from Julios.
Appearance : Clear yellow with small white head. Some lacing.

Aroma : Floral and grassy. Citrusy with notes of mangos and passion fruits. Light piny notes. Nice malt as well. 

Taste : Crisp and floral. Nice malt with light piny notes and slightly resinous. 

Palate : Soft carbonation. Fairly dry and rather thin body. A little bit thin on the finish but thats understandable.

Overall : Realy nice drinkable beer. A bit thin compared to other examples of the same style. Nice aroma and taste. Nice soft palate. Nice floral hops. Overall a great beer.

Bottle; poured a dull goldish color with a pure white head. Aroma was vibrant and pungent. Funky BO, earth, fruit and pine. Hoppy. Flavor oozed a hop presence, body was a bit thin. Drinkable, despite the flavor profile.
Pours a nice clear golden color with white head and some nice lacing. Floral notes dominate the nose, a little citrus, and a little pine; follows onto the palate. Finishes with some nice hop resin.

ホップがすご  
苦味が強すぎ&

Probably my favorite hoppy beer froms tone really. Poured a light yellow color with a white head. Aroma was of big citrusy and lightly tropical hops, mild grapefruit too. Flavor was similar, more on the tropical side than most stone ipas but still grapefruit there too, a bbit watered down even for a session, but still really solid, would love if i could get this for a reasonable price.

Bottle from Hunger N Thirst. Pours golden with a half inch of white foam. Massively fragrant notes on the nose almost like grapefruit perfume. Nice hoppy notes in the tongue. Flavorful with a slight hint of bitterness on the tongue. Simply fantastic!

I like this one a lot. Yellow color and a white head that goes away quickly. The grapefruit hops aroma is very strong. The taste follows along the same lines, grapefruit, a bit biting, and a bitter aftertaste. Light body and very drinkable, especially with the low ABV. Admittedly, the bitterness is a bit jarring, but if you like grapefruit, bitter hops that are very in-your-face, youll love this beer.

Clear golden with a thick white head. Aroma is strong grapefruit and astringent hops. Flavor is big grapefruit with a light body and a good dose of bitterness. Very drinkable if a bit bitter in the finish.

Wife: 3.6

Bottle pour light golden. Nose huge tropical fruit, papaya, mango, some pine. Very aromatic. Taste again the tropical fruit hops. Reasonable bitterness. Very hop forward and I like it. Pleasing light bitter finish. Yep, I could drink a lot of these.

UPDATED: JUN 12, 2015 this is a nice beer with a peculiar aroma. opening the bottle i at first thought id acquired another skunky beer. failed to identify the smell but it sure is weird. taste is nice and bitter, though. good aftertaste. overall quite pleasant.

update: this brew has moved to the top of my favourites list. still has that curious aroma but i love the taste. a keeper.

Bottle. Pours a slightly hazy golden color with a light white head. Aroma is big time fruity hops. Wow, like a passion fruit or some type of berry? Tropical for sure. Quite aromatic. Flavor is dry and hoppy, tropical fruit, slight sweetness with a dry finish. Bitter fruit over the palate. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Draft pour on tap at Emporium (Chicago, IL). Pours a firm striking darker deep orange amber hue. Faint haze but near transparent as that deep orange glow flows throughout. Frothy whitish head atop stays as a decent layer, sticks around and laces well enough. Aromas are firmly hoppy, citrus and tropical fruit meet florals, touches of bread, more fruit, grass. Initial is medium bodied, a firm bitter hop element hits the palate, juicy fruit and tropical elements meet florals, citrus, and earth. A decent sweetness really hits the palate, fruity and integrated well but still a bit much for me in this particular style niche. Backend is still fairly bitter, lingering grainy and bready malts meet tropical fruit, citrus and florals. The nose is potent, the beer itself seems a bit girthy for the Session IPA trend but certainly is tasty. A solid beer albeit a bit misplaced.

12 oz bottle from Premier Gourmet in Buffalo, served in a stem glass. Pours clear golden with a tall white head that fades to a thin remnant and leaves a small amount of fine lace. The nose has huge skunky notes, along with resin, cat pee and subtle pale malts. The flavour is mildly sweet up front with pale malts, grains and grass. The hops pick up through the middle, imparting a peppery, catty and somewhat resinous bitterness. The finish is long and bitter with a nice pepperiness. On the palate it is light-medium in body with a smooth, slightly dry texture and soft carbonation. Overall a decent light IPA with a soft nose and prominent bitter finish. Nice, but not the most complex. 2014-05-02

I was planning on having any beer tonight but saw this and figured a session IPA is barely drinking so picked it up. Pours pale clear gold. Nose is nice tropical fruits and pine. Tastes floral, of guava, mango, cereal, pine,and ginger. Light bodied and perfectly sessionable I supposed..

12 oz bottle. Pours clear, pale gold/yellow. White head with okay retention. Aroma initially is bread and grass, followed by pine and grapefruit after its been in the glass a few minutes. Dry with grassy bitter finish. Light body, lively carbonation. Overall: Ive been drinking session IPAs like a fiend this season. Last year I could find only one, and now they seem to be everywhere, some more sessionable than others. Anyway, this one is pretty similar to the others, and totally fits the low alcohol (and low-ish calorie), nice flavor bill. Hope this niche lasts, and that neither I nor the market lose interest, because otherwise I dont know what the hell Im going to be able to drink at night when Im dieting.
Tastes mainly of pine and tropical fruit. Refreshing like Miller Lite or some such garbage, but it actually tastes really good. Another Stone home run.

Pours a clear golden with a medium white head and some lacing. Aroma is citrus fruit and piney hops. Flavor is fruity with citrus zest and notes of pine with nice hop bitterness on the finish. Medium body with medium carbonation. Pretty good.

12 oz bottle. Pours hazy golden with short lived, fluffy white head and lively carbonation. Aroma is of citrusy hops, bready malt, piney and fruity notes. Body is full and crisp. Taste is of, citrusy herbal hops, buiscit malt and lemon zest. Finish is long, and very bitter. There is some mismatch of hop profile in this brew.

On tap at Brunzies. Awesome fresh hop aroma, grassy, earthy, funky. Sweet notes with sticky apricot and pineapple. Medium golden amber clear with light haze, topped with creamy-foamy white lacing head. Medium body with medium-high carbonation. Moderately sweet start with light honey, attenuated beautifully with resinous and ozone hop bitterness, tropical fruit esters. Smooth hoppy finish with clear after, a lingering tropical fruit quality.

Session IPAs are becoming more prevalent out there at the moment, and Stones Go To IPA comes with a lot of anticipation. A drinkable, lower ABV IPA that comes across as flavorful and fully hopped as a beer pushing 6%+. Large pine and sap notes with a bitterness and a pleasing citrus feel. Has all the flavor you are looking for in a good IPA with a low enough alcohol content to allow you to enjoy this at any time.

Pours a hay colored pale yellow with a white head that leaves a slight lacing. Aromas of grapefruit and mandarin oranges. Taste is a little on the bitter side but it is expected with the small amount of malts in this one and the big hop aroma. Light and easy drinking.

12 oz bottle from Sprouts market. Pours a hazy gold color with a small white head that has fair retention. The aroma is distinct with pine, grapefruit and some smell that I find characteristic in many Stone brews and is likely the yeast strain they use. The taste is bitter hops forward with light pine, grapefruit , musty mandarin oranges and a bit of salt. The malt base is a Pils base and suits this beer well. The palate is full bodied and smooth and the carbonation is soft. Finishes short and dry. Overall: Superb session IPA, I loved it.
Strong piney scent. Strong citrus notes. Noticeable grapefruit flavor with a strong hoppy finish. This beers bitterness definitely stays on the pallet.

12 Fl. Oz. Bottle. Poured clear in a light shade of yellow with a small white head and lots of sticky lacing on the glass. Aroma of citrus fruit, grass and floral and pine notes. Taste is bitter but with a mild maltiness to it. Nice, very enjoyable beer.

Pours a nice clean medium golden color with a finger of white foam. Nice balance of hop forward fruit, citrus and some earthy straw notes. Melon rind, orange zest Tight bitterness, earthy spice on the finish. Solid and flavorful offering.
Poured from a 375 mL bottle. Pours clear yellow amber with a white head. Flavour is citrus, pineapple, pine, and subtle malts. Flavour follows the nose. Solid IPA.

On tap 6 oz. sampler at The Bistro in Old Line Wine in Beltsville, MD. 

Clear, yellow-straw -gold with an off-white head and excellent lacing. 

Aroma of bright citrus and grapefruit rind. 

Taste of grapefruit rind and caramel. 

Medium/full body and medium/low carbonization.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Poured from a 12 ounce bottle. Big juicy hop aroma, tropical fruits, citrus, pine, soft catty notes as well as a light green onion. The malts are soft and bready. Not bad, however the onion is kind of killing this one for me.

Bottle:
Pours an active, cloudy citrus gold with a small off-white head.
Strong grapefruit-peel, resin aroma.
Taste is smoky, grapefruit-peel, pine-tar...tangerine...biscuit.
Wow...this is a really great and full flavoured SIPA.

From the 12 fl. oz. bottle that says "Enjoy Fresh" but I see no bottling date anywhere on it. I hope it is fresh. Seems to be because the hazy yellow pour leads to a floral and earthy hops penetration of my nose like a laser while the toasted pale malts creep up in the background. Medium body. Smooth. Drinkable. A quick appetizer of toasted pale biscuit malts erupt into a floral and grassy hop flavor. Hops outperform the malts for sure but at the same time it seems balanced. Brilliant bitter finale.

Fantastic floral bouquet of marigolds, lillies, rosehips, tangerines, and just a wee bit of cat pee. Hazy golden, thick head, good lacing. Less fruity on the palate, lillies and lemongrass. Mild maltiness on the back. Medium body, dry, slightly oily. Stellar and easily met high expectations.

Bottle from Tipples. Pours a perfectly clear light golden color with a one finger creamy white head. Big hops aroma with pineapple, honey, grapefruit, citrus peel, grass. Flavor is light malts stuck behind bright grassy hops with notes of citrus peel and pineapple throughout. Medium bitter. Light bodied with plenty of carbonation, finishing slightly dry. Probably the best of the light IPAs.

Best session IPA I've ever had. You could have told me this was 8% it has such an intense delicious perfect IPA taste. Had it in draft at Nepenthe in big sur. light orange and clear pour. Fruity citrus aroma. Hoppy floral grapefruit taste. Stone nailed the session IPA

Pours a very clean and bright lemon rind yellow with two fingers of sticky white head. Beautiful appearance. Lightly grassy nose with some soft fruity/citrusy notes and light peachy notes. Very dry flavor and somewhat astringent in the finish. Green hop notes, not too hot on this one.

Stolen from my office hurray: Pours golden orange with a white head. Aroma is peach, citrus, with a bare hint of malts. Anyway the taste is a little bitter. There are loads of grapefruit, really, straight up fresh grapefruit, not what we normally call grapefruit in a beer. Pretty unique in its flavor even if it is a subdued style. Quite good. Job well done.

Poured from bottle into pint glass: Pours clear gold with a thin white head. Floral aroma with hints of resin, grass, tropical fruits, and grapefruit. Taste is not at all sweet, floral, light citrus and pine. Light to medium body, nice hop kick at the end, not overly bitter. Clean, dry finish. This is an awesome session IPA. Probably the best one Ive had that wasnt Hill Farmstead.

Bottle @ home, picked up at Wilburs Fort Collins. Pours a golden orange appearance with a lasting off white head. Plenty of juicy / tropical fruity hops in the nose with a bit of spice (onion). Nice body. Minimal malt. Some cracker. A bit of garlic and onion. Guava, mango, and tangerine. One of the best Session IPAs Ive had yet (but still not a style Im crazy about).

Golden with white head a thick lacing. Citrus and flora aroma. Taste - Strong citrus hops dominate. Notes of grapefruit, lemon zest and touch of resinous pine and flowers. Hops laid down on top of light biscuit malt. Crazy good full flavored ale for such a light body and low ABV. Goes down so easy for a highly hopped IPA. Great flavor.

UPDATED: MAY 16, 2014 bottle. clear gold with a small and stable head. this beer is awesome! i havent been truly impressed with this style until now. the palates are usually overly dry and hops are usually too bitter. the palate is superb here. easily drinkable, moderate carbonation and not dry as a bone. light bodied. a joy to drink.

Pours a clear orange golden color with a fluffy head which lingers. Aroma is overwhelming citrus. Taste is heavy citrus, fair mouthfeel up front, slight biscuit then pleasing bitterness which lingers just a bit. Well build for a session brew.
On tap @ Radio Maria. Intense white grapefruit aroma with touches of pine. Sharp and crisp, with fresh grapefruit hop character, vibrant. Finishes dry, bitter, and clean. Insane drinkability. Wow!
user_location: the land of bitumen, beef & beer, Alberta, CANADA

text:
12oz bottle into a pint glass.

Pours a slightly hazy dirty dark yellow with just a tiny fizzy white head. No lacing and pretty poor head retention.

Aroma is an awesome juicy tropical fiesta! Huge punch of mango and tangerine that is absolutely mouthwatering. I cant really detect any malt but that is to be expected in a light session beer.

The flavor is just as great as the aroma. Tons of tropical fruit in abundance with a huge hop bitterness. The juiciness is just incredible and really makes up for the lack of malt and body. Bitterness continues through the finish.

Overall, I really love this beer. An awesome session IPA with great hop character. Unfortunately, the price is a bit steep to make it truly sessionable.

Golden copper, nice fluffy white head. Big citrus hop aroma, plus some steel and light smoke. Smooth and crisp, very drinkable. Definite grapefruit, some pine. I would drink a lot of this if I could get it here...

Aroma of citrus, lemon, melon, grapefruit, herbal hops, mango and pines. Appearance is a completely see through gold with a thin foam rim. Taste is dry hops upfront with a juicy grapefruit, melon, peach, mango mix thereafter. Bittersweet caramel, bread, biscuit malt body holds it together. Overall, this is fantastic. The fact that its 4.5% abv yet doesnt taste watery at all is really impressive. Best session ale Ive ever had. A rating.

Very good, very good, but not go to. Nearly clear yellow pour with a bright white head. Aroma is lemon rind, yeast and funky hops. Taste follows the nose. I will not passnon this if offered. Very good, but no 90 minute.
A yellow color with a white head. Aroma contains some pine and citrus. The flavor is hoppy with some oranges and lemons. Not much malt in this and a dry finish. Overall a good session IPA.

A new Stone IPA is a cause for celebrating! Btw I think it is a little silly to have a separate category for session IPAs. There is lots of fresh citrus peel in the aroma, along with dashes of honey and yeasty funk. The taste is dry and peppy.  Stone used a new "hop bursting" technique for this release. For a lighter beer, this is really packed with hop flavor and has a lot of resinous character. This is definitely all about the hops - it is a little unbalanced, but still very good. The label doesnt tell you what kind of hops are used - Amarillo maybe? This is the hoppiest 4.2 ABV brew Ive ever tried - it is hop juice, baby!

Sharp and astringent session beer, initial hops blast is puckering. Lots of pine in this puppy, but overall light mouthfeel. Weight is also light, making this an easy drinker. Getting used to the hops attack up front, this gets better as you sip.
Finally an IPA that doesnt try to hide its true nature. Its bitter and bold, and I like it.
Pours gold with white head and no lacing.  Aroma of citrus, tropical fruit, and pine hops. Taste is resin and bitter. Excellent session.  Taste like a big IPA, but without the high alcohol.

UPDATED: FEB 11, 2016 Clear to hazy golden pour with a thin white head and light sticky lacing .... Aroma of mangos and piney hops with a nice citrusy burst of grapefruit as well ...... Taste is bitter and piney and of mango grapefruity hops with some oily mouthfeel...... Has a resiny and rindy mouthfeel and taste ... Finish is bitter piney and lingers a little. ... Nice solid easy drinking IPA

12 oz. bottle from Wilburs. Appearance: 2 fingers white head that lasts for a bit, clear straw yellow, ok lacing. Aroma: caramel, floral, grapefruit. Palate: light body, average carbonation, lasting bitter finish, sticky and refreshing texture. Taste: nice rush of sweetness and a quick transition into full headed hoppiness with sweet undertones. Overall, solid, as all Stone IPAs are. harsher balance than most, but still a good balance.
Bottle. Great beer with fresh citrus aroma.Nice bitter taste with tones of citrus.

Draft at sb. Pours a crystal clear medium gold with a dense and fizzy white head. Bright sweet pine and grass and floral nose. Creamy medium body with lively carb. Caramel and piney resin on the mid palate with a long dry resiny finish.
Honestly. This is fucking ridiculous. It makes Founders All Day IPA look like a pansie. Seriously shitting bricks, this is awesome

Bottle. Pour is pale yellow with a medium white head. Aroma is hop citrus, pine needles, and grass. Flavor is extremely bitter and unbalanced, no malt presence with a harsh finish. Youd have to be an extreme lover of hops to ever want to have this twice.

Aroma: slightly citrus but weak. App: deep golden yellow, no head.taste: overpoweringly bitter, pine on the finish. Palate: dry, like suck the water out of my mouth dry. Overall: this is billed as a session beer and no way I could do more then one without drinking some water. Not impressed.

12oz bottle - alittle disappointed by this one , great juicy citrus and pine aromas , great color , did not deliver on the taste . Weak sauce , even for a session ipa . 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Very skunked aroma, followed by off flavors and overly bitter notes. Looks like Coors Light or something along those lines. I think this is rated well on here!?! Easily my least favorite Stone beer of all time. Not interested in the concept, and I have no idea why they would mess with this low-abv nonsense.

This beer isn't bad. It is lighter in color and has a floral smell and taste. The finish is also floral in nature. Overall not bad but not my favorite

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
Definitely not a fan of this one. Really pronounced earthy/grassy raw hop cone character, very high bitterness for the style. Flavor is palatable but not entirely desirable.

12 oz bottle. Aroma is extremely citrusy along with some peach, earthiness. Pours hazy pale golden with a large white fluffy head with excellent retention. Taste is bittersweet but doesnt have near the bitterness as most of their other hop-forward beers. Light bodied and highly carbonated. I was skeptical, but this lived up to the hype.

Tap - small foamy head, mildly hazy golden color, nice big lemon/grapefruit hop aroma and flavor, pretty mild malt backbone, nice dry bitter finish - very good for a session IPA

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
Light, off yellow pour. No head. Nose is citrus hops. Bitter. Middle tastes like someone spilled water in my beer...not bad....just not complete. Finish brings me back with hop bitterness. OK.

Bottle. Light yellow pour. Very nice aroma of grapefruit and pine. Flavor is also grapefruit and pine. Flavor lacks a malt background and thus the flavor of the beer seems a little incomplete. Body is light.

Une petite bouteille qui renferme un liquide jaune et voilé. Une mousse convaincante. Dès louverture de la bouteille, des parfums concentrés de houblons envahissent la chambre. Mon nez est agréablement attaqué par des fleurs, des herbes, des feuilles, du zeste de citron mais aussi par dautres de fruits tropicaux. Une première gorgée pour me rendre compte que mes papilles seront grandement traitées. Une base maltée bien pâle et sèche tempère avec justesse les houblons jeunes et fous qui bâtissent des saveurs franches de fleurs poivrées, dherbes vertes, daiguilles de pin et de fruits acidulés juteux. En bouche, le liquide a un corps bien léger et assez pétillant. Cette structure colle très bien à la définition du style. En finale, les cultivars assèchent considérablement et piquent avec fougue. Très belle bière de soif parfaitement sculpté pour mon palais qui a actuellement très chaud.

Bottle thrown at me by Douglas. 

A: Pale yellow with a fluffy white head and good retention. Nice lacing. 

N: Good hopping - pine, earth, and grapefruit are predominant. Cracker underneath. 

T: Moderately bitter - though the bitterness is sharp in nature. Not much malt sweetness here. 

M: A touch watery, but the alpha acids still do some cutting. 

O: A nice beer, though its not really that different of an offering from their regular lineup, is it?
Another hit from stone. Best described as a session IPA. Plenty of hoppy bitterness but not too much.
12 oz bottle pours a golden orange color with a nice white head. Aromas of light pine, grapefruit, lemon. Medium bodied, light refreshing and good

Pine, grapefruit, earthy, and caramel aroma notes. Golden with white head. Mild white lacing. Medium bodied, lemon and earthy mix, grassy-pine notes, and sour notes. Dry front, watery finish with medium lasting bitterness. ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

I had this at Global Brew. Pours clear gold with a white head. Taste pine, fruity, hoppy. I thought this was pretty good. I would drink this again.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Man this is a beauty for the ABV. Lots of grapefruit and floral notes, some light malt in the background. Tastes are medium/heavy bitter and very light sweet. Full sticky body with lively carbonation. Awesome!

Bright yellow in color with a white head. Big, fresh, clean hop aroma. Taste is well balanced but favors bitter. Soft on the palate and the finish is clean, this goes down real easy. Very well made session IPA.
Lightly hazed yellow body. Bone white head. Intense catty hops turn into orange peels in the flavor. Not much malt character.
Bottle; clear yelliw with medium white head; aroma-grapefruit, pine, fruits; taste- moderate bitterness, mild sweetness. Bitter long finish. They have done better.
Draft @ Three Fires. Juicy fruity citrus, floral, grassy hops aroma. Clear yellow with a moderate white head. Citrus, earthy piney hops flavor. Body on the light side of medium, soft carbonation.

Sample from tap, at Encinitas Alehouse. Clear golden blonde color. Aromas of pine needles, citrus/sour fruit, flowery hops. Retronasal the flowery hops are upfront, along with with resin and grapefruit. Flavor is bitter, somewhat earthy. Light bodied. Finishes slightly dry, nicely bitter, not too harsh. Lovely, tasty, sessionable IPA.

Bottle at Antenna America. Pale golden, taste is good, light bitterness, lots of fruit, grapefruit, bit grainy, dry, and slightly earthy maybe, minerals. Aroma is citrus, bit of pine. Bitterness increases further down. Good stuff. Sparkly and light! Refreshing!

Bottle from Hot and Soul in Ft. Lauderdale, FL. Pours a sparkling clear gold with a medium white fluffy head that lasted and laced. Aroma was very pungent hops...pine, resin, fresh cut pasture, light citrus. The taste almost didnt live up to the aroma but as you breathed in each sip it was just fine. Bitter, light body, light alcohol. Crisp finish. Good balance.

4/19/2014: Stone Go To IPA... Hazy pale yellow color with a large, pillowy off-white head. Aroma is an odoriffic combination of papaya, grapefruit, and melon with just a bit of floral notes. The aroma is definitely bursting with hops! The flavor is the liquid form of the aroma. The toffee maltiness is super light and stays out of thy way of the great hoppy flavor. This beer is only mildly bitter and there is quite a bit of hoppy goodness (floral, passion fruit, grapefruit, pine, a touch of grass) without being just a hop bomb. This beer is lightweight with a slick texture. I like it a lot. I dont know how they did it, but they did a great job making an uber-flavorful and hoppy beer without it being too malty, sweet, bitter, or high in alcohol. Ive been on the hunt for great low alcohol beers for years and Im so happy to see so many breweries finially getting on board with the idea and putting out some great beer thats low in alcohol. Nicely done! 12 fl. oz. bottle (4.5% Alc/Vol; Enjoy by 5/25/2014) from Party Town in Florence, KY. Rating #309 for this beer.

Great aroma. I didnt want to drink it - I just wanted to smell this all day. Poured light gold with slight white head. Taste was slight bitter and for a sessionable IPA I enjoyed it greatly. It didnt have any overpowering citrus or light notes.

Pour - hazy gold

Mouth - high carb 

Aroma - heavy cat pee smell

Taste - closer to a regular IPA than founders but for me the hop profile was slightly off so I prefer founders more

Overall - still a great session beer.

Pours pale golden yellow. Big hop nose, sticky floral hops. Hops carry thru on the palate, but finishes clean and crisp and doesn't linger very long. Goes down very easy. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

perfect clear yellow. Big tropical fruit, and lemon zest on the nose. A hint of dank hops. Very crisp and light bodied. Bitter but not too bitter. Tons more lemon zest a and tropical fruit hop notes. Excellent.
Pours a pale gold with a small white head. Smells of spruce, grapefruit, hint of funky skunk - so good. Taste is bitter and mildly sweet - spruce hops, citrus, mild maltiness.

12oz bottle poured into my ipa glass. Pours a clear yellow color with a thick white head that leaves great lacing. Smell of pine, grapefruit, citrus and mango. Tastes of the same things with a good hop bite. Mouthfeel is light and chewy with great carbonation and a dry finish. Props to stone for finally making an ipa with full flavor and lower abv. Great hop presence and malt balance. Definitely for hop heads still.

Enjoy by 5/25. $2.19 single. Poured into a Sam Adams Perfect Pint.

Appearance: Perfectly clear yellow color with two fingers of white head on it that dies down fairly quickly. A good amount of lacing. A lot of carbonation coming up from the glass as well.

Smell: Nice sweet hop aroma. A bit of dankness. Just a lot of pine, citrus, and a bit of mango sort of smells in here. Candied sweetness there as well that puts it over the top. Definitely the highlight of this brew -- it just smells incredibly refreshing.

Taste/feel: Actually a fair amount like the aroma. Go To has a surprising flavor for a beer so low in ABV. Theres a wallop of hops, but still a pleasant malt presence that prevents the beer from tasting like hop water, like I remember Founders All Day IPA tasting like (I should revisit that though). Just a great, fresh hop flavor. Wow. Like the smell, a nice blend of pine, citrus, and tropical notes. A solid to-be-expected IPA bitterness at the end, but its not at all overwhelming. Light feel, as youd probably expect, with very high drinkability.

Great beer to be sure, not just for the fact its 4.5%. $2.19 for a single though? I could just buy a sixer of Two Hearted for less and call it a day. I can see the time and place for this beer no doubt, but the price is too high for my liking.

Excellent session IPA. 4.5% that tastes like a triple. The hop-bursting brings out a strong hop bite in smell and taste. 

Not for everyone. But if you are a hop head and want a great poolside beer the look no further. 

- Snowboards and IPA

Color is ok, Ive seen more beautiful beers. Head fizzles down pretty quickly. Smells and tastes bitter/hoppy like an IPA, but its quite low in alcohol for the style (4.5%). Its pretty good. Ill drink them.

No way is this a session! From a bottle smells like B/O. Seems like a high alky beer to me....big ipa flavor on a low alky session? Chewing on grapefruit rinds. Yes, it is the terrible flavor of ipa, but its light in alky and calories, best call it a light ipa. Pretty funny we have a category called session IPA. HA HA! best call it a light beer. If cheap pale lager cant have their light beers called a session lager, then forget about this stupid new style WAHHHHW! As usual, stone makes them on style you old stalwart.
user_location: Beaver Valley, Beaver County, Pennsylvania, USA

text: From a bottle into a wheat beer style glass. Wonderful aroma of hoppy pine, grapefruit. Full flavored, crisp, mildly bracing pine and grapefruit. Well done start to finish. Lower alcohol but full flavor? Good idea.
Amazing a beer this low in alcohol can taste so big. Juicy grapefruit and pine without being palate-wreckingly bitter. Possibly my new go-to IPA. See what I did there?

Pours a very bright and clear yellow with a more full, frothy white head. A fresh aroma holds big grapefruit, pineapple, lemon, floral hops, and light pine. The taste is dry and bitter. Grapefruit dominates here, with pine and lemon serving as undertones. It is rather straightforward, but it is done well. Long and bitter aftertaste is grapefruit. Light in body, with a thin, sticky texture, with some lively carbonation. It is very easy to drink. This one is perfect for a warm summer afternoon.

6 pack from Wallabys best before June 25, 2014. How much do you like hops? Thats the question you have to ask yourself when you sip this one. The pour is light, almost yellow, but with a very large and frothy white head. Aroma = hops. There is basically no malt to stand in the way of the massive alpha acid onslaught and its a rich, true hop aroma much like rubbing whole cones between your thumb and fingers. Its grassy, citrusy, piney and dank with even some juicy-fruity notes for balance. The palate is light but the flavor is so completely over-the-top no fullness is missed for me in the mouthfeel. Tons of true hop flavor hits with huge citrus, pine and herbs. The finish is dry. Ive been in the mood for lighter bodied, lighter alcohol, full-flavored beers and this hits on all counts.

Poured from the tap into a Rogue pint glass.

The color is clear orange/gold with a foamy white head and some nice lacing.

The smell is bright hops with some fresh hop aroma. Fresh cut grass is in the nose with a tangerine aroma sweetening things up and making it citrus smelling.

The taste is nice piney hops with sweet light malty goodness. A nice citrus flavor with hints of tangerine and tangy grapefruit. Much like Enjoy By IPA, the flavor has that same earthy grass taste.

The feel is light bodied and goes pretty damn easy. A tasty beer in a light session-able package. Some flavor reminiscent of bigger IPAs but has lightness that is very drinkable.

12 oz bottle. Clear yellow orange with a white head. Nose is toffee, pine and orange. Soft medium body with a tingle. Taste is pine, cantaloupe, apricot and lemon pith. Hoppy bitterness with just enough fruit notes to keep it interesting.
Bottle. Grapefruit, pine, caramel and some tropical fruit. A bit resiny with a mild bitterness throughout. Solid IPA finish. Tasty.

12oz bottle. Not gonna go crszy as this will get tons of rates. Poured a clear rusty amber with a smaller foamy white head. AROMA/FLAVOR of dankness, weed, citrus, rotting citrus, earth, some sugar sweetness, dough and wet bread. Solid stuff.

Its a terrific summer oriented IPA. Fresh thanks to the Citrus notes. Very drinkable. This is the kind of beer I love, with a strong character, they are not looking for a perfect balance recipe, with this beer they move straight to the point, take or leave it. well done! recommended

Stone Go To IPA has a thick, white head, a mostly clear, somewhat bubbly, burnished gold appearance, and a bit of lacing left behind. The aroma is very much hop oriented: a very strong pineapple note with a background hop resin. Taste is the same, with a noticeable, yet pleasant bitterness. There is some sweet malt showing itself, too. Mouthfeel is light to medium and a bit slick, and Stone Go To IPA finishes semi-dry and easy drinking. RJT

Bottle. Amber beer with a cream head. Big tropical fruit aroma with grapefruit. Grapefruit and pine flavor with tropical fruit. Medium bodied. Good bitterness. Grapefruit and pine linger with tropical fruit.
Amber colored, moderate head, decent lace/retention. Aroma of grapefruit, citrus, light caramel, some cereal and bread. Low bitterness, very drinkable - and thats the idea. Pretty cool.

Poured from a 12oz bottle

Aroma - HUGE hop aroma, peach, pineapple - amazing tropical aroma.

Appearance - Clear golden color. Head disapates quickly.

Taste - Good IPA. A lot of carbination. Obviously light mouth feel, but considering 4.5%, that isnt suprising.

Palate - Nice lingering taste, fizzy with a bitter after taste.

Overall - For a session IPA, its amazing they got all of those hops in a 4.5% beer. New lawnmower beer.
Pretty light. Cloudy gold color. Lacing. Aroma of grapefruit orange. Overall ok...

12 oz bottle- Pours hazy straw golden with a thick pillowy white head with great retention. Aroma is pungent piney hops, citrus, what you want in an IPA. The taste is resinous pine, citrus, dare I say dank! Nice beer, hopefully this stays in my area year round.
12oz bottle. Poured a golden color with an averaged sized head. Floral hops, grassy, and citrus. Nice and hoppy for a 4% beer!
Grapefruit citrus. Thin and fizzy. Good lacing. Nice spring season. Clear yellow.

Bottle at home. Huge aroma of stonefruits. Apricot, peach, oranges, floral. Flavor mirrors the nose, with a bit of black pepper spiciness. Bitter but not astringent. The thin body only adds to the drinkability and is more than welcome. This "hop bursting" shit works. The low alcohol allows the true essence of the west coast hops to shine. Excellent.

Draught at Stone World Bistro Liberty Station, San Diego. Clear golden beer with a nice white head. Hoppy citrus aroma, pine apples, mango, oranges, grapes, passion fruit, caramel, hay, some peach. Hoppy pine apple flavor, citrus, peach, mango, raisins, floral notes. Hoppy fruity finish with citrus and pine apples. Slightly thin bodied but hugely drinkable.
On tap at Flying Sauce. Pours a clear light gold with a nice white head. Aroma of passion fruit and pine. Fruity melon and grapefruit flavor, light in body, pleasant sweetness with a crisp finish.

12oz bottle, that pours clear pale gold. A great mix of citrus, pine, grass, and fruit aromas. Hops and bitter foward, and all the way to the finish and then some. Spicy with a lite body. Refreshing. This will replace some of the summer beers I usually drink.
Pours clear golden color with white head. Aromas of citrus, pine and grass. Grass and pine flavors with some bitter and sweet grapefruit. Medium body with average carbonation. Decent.

Pours a clear copper color with a medium white sticky head. A rich floral and fruity nose. Rich fruity brew, no bitterness, oranges, all hop bursting freshness. Honestly, the flavor here is awesome especially considering the low gravity. Just massive. Light beer for sure, but good.

(bottle - 12 oz) Clear gold pour with a fizzy white head. Piney and slightly citrusy hop aroma. Not very citrusy in the flavor bit has a really nice earthiness and a deep lingering bitter note. Bitter aftertaste.
12 ounce bottle. Pours a clear light gold with a nice white head. Aroma of citrus, floral, and malt. Taste is grapefruit, lemon, pine, floral, and malt. Pretty good.

355ml bottle. Along wiht Easy JAck this is a highly-respactible session ipa. Tastes like a normal west coaster but at 4.5%. This is more resinoius, bitter, and dank than the FW but it isnt as tropical or sluggable.

I think I like this trend of hoppy session beers way more than bourbon barrel aging every goddamn beer on the planet. There have been some ups and downs and in betweens and I was excited to find Stone did an excellent job with Go To. Orange pour, white head with big fresh aroma of citrus, mango, light pine, light toast. The flavors are bright, bitter, crisp and lightly sweet. The body is light, and with most sessions I find the body so light that its almost thin/watery, though Go To does a pretty good job of maintaining that threshold, but it is indeed present. The finish, much like the rest of the beer is bright and bitter. Overall its a great session, and as long as I can get get it fresh, I imagine Ill drink a decent amount of this summer. Although I didnt find it surprising that Stone made this beer, I always thought Levitation was their session, which I truly hope they keep both as they are both fantastic yet different hoppy session offerings.

Had this one a couple of times but finally getting around to reviewing one of the last bottles left in my fridge... Picked this up at the COOP a couple weeks ago.. Pours a crystal clear golden with a short lived white head.

Nose is huge hop-forward tropical fruits with plenty of pithy citrus zest for so little malt backbone.. almost too much, but I really like it nonetheless.

This tastes like my idea of summertime brews! Very hoppy and still balanced.. bitterness melts back fast into the pithy hops with just enough melon and finishes back bitter with a dry pale maltiness...

Light body... nice bubble... incredibly drinkable especially for Stone..

Bottle - clear gold with a frothy, fairly thick, well-sustained head - nose is all hops - some pleasanf citrus and pine, but also some unpleasant garlic and diesel - soft carbonation - surprisingly sweet at first, but the sweetness is clean, simple, and short-lived - pretty much all hops after that - peppery/spicy, citric, a little tropical fruit before a very spicy finish - okay.

Tasted on 4/9/14 from a capped 12oz bottle purchased at Craft Brewed. Pours hazy dark yellow with a thin white head that leaves thin, bubbly lace. The nose is completely dominated by hops with tons of dank, grassy resin aroma, floral tropical fruit, and citrus blossom and just a touch of doughy yeast. The flavor is not quite as exciting, but very nicely dry with the hops showing fairly bitter (a touch astringent), with more grassy pine resin than anything else. The body is light with lively carbonation and a long bitter dank hops finish. This is really quite excellent.
bottle, one of the better sessional IPAs out there. great big hop filled aroma. piney, citrusy notes. great flavor, better aroma. nice

Has good taste up front. A strong bitter 
end. Pours a good head. I thought the flavors of citrus were good. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

12 oz. bottle, pours a clear pale golden with a small white head. Aroma brings out lovely floral hops, crisp biscuity malts, and some fruitiness. Flavour is dry and bitter, with loads of floral hops, soapy notes and crisp dry biscuity notes. Very dry, very bitter and hoppy. Refreshing, but missing something. Decent stuff.

560 yen +tax bottle from Craft Beer Base. My first impression is a session IPA should be priced below 500 yen. Anyways, on to the beer: it pours a deep gold but a touch lighter than I like. The head is thick & foamy but quickly dissipating. It packs a huge hop bouquet made up citrus, pine needles & resin. A deliciously herbaceous funky nose. The body is medium-light with a soft round mouthfeel. The taste is fairly straight up bitter piney & herbal with some citrus in the nose. Quite good stuff, the aroma is the star & the taste doesnt quite match it. Definitely worth trying for hop heads.

Bottle from Canals Hammonton. Pours out a mostly clear golden color with a small white head and a healthy does of carbonation. Aroma is of fruity/piney/melon hops, lots of fruit and some light grainy bread. Taste is a ton of fruity hops, tropical fruits, melon, light pine and some sweet floral characteristics, mild grainy malts. Really clean tasting with a nice dose of bitterness that lingers on the tongue. Stone can do no wrong when it comes to hoppy beer.

Bottle. A month or so old but didnt really show. Pours a very clear yellow with white head. Aroma is dank cat piss and pepper. Taste is a very thin but hoppy beer. The dankness is still there and you get a fair amount of fruit in this but the palate is just so thin. I think this is more to do with me wanting a standard IPA in every way but alcohol which just isnt possible. I also dont find myself routinely wanting to drink 6+ pints in an afternoon so I guess I dont have as much need for a "session" beer.
user_location: Morro Bay via Orange County, California, USA

text: Pours a clear straw color with a white head & good lacing. Aroma of citrus and grass hops with light malt. Flavor of pine hops at the start and citrus in the finish. Bitterness all the way through. Very good for a low alcohol IPA.

I poured a 12oz bottle into a nonic pint glass. It had a best before date of 5/28/14 and cost $3.15 ($0.26).

Appearance: Lemon-skin yellow hue over a clear body with visible carbonation. Pours to a small, white, frothy head which laces and retains well.

Smell: Interesting combination of various hops, with notes of lemon, cat pee and cannabis.

Taste: Stone Brewing is known for their huge hoppy beers. Though they do make a light beer called Levitation Ale, it never really caught on. With their new Go To IPA, Stone seems to have re-invented the so-called session IPA style. This beer is exactly what it sets out to be: a light bodied brew with the hop taste and bitterness you want in an IPA. 

Obviously, the hops are the stars of the show here. But this beer opts for hop flavor rather than raw bitterness. An interesting combination of hops as well. Theres notes of herbal or skunky/earthy character that gives it a saison-like spiciness. Lemon citrus comes through the middle, which is to be expecting considering which coast this comes from. Dry bitterness on the back end with a slightly starchy/pasty aftertaste, though it fades quickly. Overall, a genuinely flavorful beer that Ill bet would fool a lot of judges in a blind tasting as it can hold its own with any other standard IPA.

Drinkability: The problem with session IPAs is they can often drink like blondes with lots of hops. Stone Go To IPA, though light in weight at only 4.5% ABV, is not a light-bodied beer. Theres genuine body to the brew. The mouthfeel is crisp, but not thin or watery. Its refreshing for a moment as it crosses the tongue, though the bitterness does linger but its easily tolerable. I could see this being ideal for summer. The only problem: its not available in cans!

12oz bottle. Pours a pale golden with a white head. Big pine aroma and flavor and huge citrus hop notes. This is the best IPA I have tasted that is less than 5% ABV. This actually stacks up to many in the 7% or higher range and is even better than alot of them. I will be making sure the fridge stays stocked with these. Great everyday beer for hopheads like me.

Bottle. Stone, making another IPA? Probably going to be good. Orange color, white head, full nose of citrus, grass, etc. Taste is smooth, easy drinking yet hoppy. No alcohol noted. Could probably drink a lot of these. Very good beer.
Great scent of citrus and pine. the flavor has a slightly sweet malt beginning but gives way to the bitter hops. Very dry and refreshing.

Bottle. Pours a clear yellow gold body under a one finger fizzy white head that had decent retention. The nose is super bright and fruity with some citrusy notes and minimal malt influence. This one is all about the hops. The hops are just as bright in the flavor, but theres just a little something about the hop mix that I dont care for all that much. I think its a heavy mango like flavor thats especially intense that I dont care for. Some pale bready maltiness on the finish along with some snappy bitterness and a lingering tropical fruit note. Light bodied and very crisp with soft gentle carbonation. Really well made beer, but I dont care all that much for the specific hops used in here.
Tap at Proof. huge pleasant citrus resin floral pine aroma. Easy drinking but seems bigger than it is. med bitter. very big creamy resin hop bomb flavor is a low abv. Nice. 7.4

UPDATED: SEP 23, 2014 Appearance: poured with a small off white head that dissipated pretty quickly, beer is a very clear gold to yellow color

Aroma: very floral, pine, grass, earth, citrus, smells really good

Taste: very pale grain, grass, pine, citrus, pretty strong bitterness on the finish 

Palate: lively carbonation, light mouthfeel, bitter aftertaste, 

Overall: this is delicious, could definitely drink a few of these, all hops but much more than bitterness, malt gets out of the way of this one, one of my favorite beers because of the taste

A lightly hazed golden ipa with a thin off white head. In aroma, classic biscuit malt with grassy floral hops, grapefruit pulp, classic, In mouth, a nice ipa with grassy biscuit malt, floral and resinous hops, medium bodied, classic goto ipa.

Had on tap at Bohemian Bull. Pours on the yellow side of IPA spectrum. Nose and palate full of tons of citrus and pine. Solid hop flavor and finish without being overpowering to the palate or alcohol content. One of my favorites for sessionability without sacrificing flavor.

Bottle from Asahiya. Deep resinous nose, pesticide strength. Medium straw color. Massive pine initial / light grainy malt and some dried fruit / tingly hoppiness / very considerable hop tracks in final. Medium body with tongue-coating hops. Fun stuff. The nose is wonderful, but in the flavor the hoppiness gets a bit wearying after some time.

Near gold pour with a 1 finger, creamy to soapy white head that has good retention and leaves a little lacing. Aroma is loaded with tangerine citrus, tropical fruit, pineapple and passion fruit heavy, a little lemon and hints of biscuit. Flavor is biscuit and tree fruit esters up front, then some nice citrus zest, tropical fruit, fruity and floral hops, with a nice crisp minerality and a pretty big dose of hop acids to the finish. Light body, creamy to dusty feel, with that hop acid twang kicking in toward the crisp, dry finish. Really good stuff, lots of tasty hop aroma and flavor in a clean, easy going package.

16oz pint at Partisan DC. Pours a clear gold with some lacing, white head. Nose has plenty of pithy hop, lemon, light pine, light soap, a hint of dry cracker. Flavor follows suit, mild malt, mild cracker, lemon, pine, soap. Dry finish. Drinkable.

Pours clear gold with short lived head. Smell is very green and pot like initially and a bit fruity. Nice and vibrant strong, inviting aroma. Taste is very hoppy, but the bitterness is kind of restrained. This is very sessionable and easy to drink. Quite tasty. Wife says it tastes like sweet poison and smells like sweet berries.

Pours light straw yellow with a frothy white top. Aroma is intense citrus Simcoe hops. Such great aroma. Taste is a blast of hop bitterness that you expect from Stone. But the flavour stays where other sessions with fall off. Best session beer Ive had yet. Awesome, need this as my "Go to"

While I usually prefer big ABV beers with big flavor Im starting to see the attractiveness of finding lower ABV beers with big flavor. This has exactly that. Like drinking a 6-7% ABV IPA but it is the same ABV as the domestic light dog piss beer everyone else around me is drinking. Works out better in my favor when outside all day in the heat or trying to hang with friend drinking low ABV stuff while I try to crush 3 bottles of Enjoy By and getting cross eyed in the first hour of the evening. Although Im still not completely against doing it anyway.

Bottle. Right up there with Lagunitas' daytime session beer. This probably beats it for me. Yes, it has a cat piss and floral aroma but it subsequently leads to a great dry hopped hop goodness finish! 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Tallahassee, Fl - Proof Brewing Company - on tap. Sparkling light golden pour, light bubbly off-white head. Aroma of cat urine and spruce. Very bitter grapefruit citrus notes. Solid, but pretty one dimensional - no real malty backbone. Thick enough moutfeel.

Clear, pale gold with a carpeting white head. Good tap handle. Medium sweetnes, lemon-orange gel hop aroma. Peppery hops, starchy mouth, herbal-vegetal backend. Light caramel notes towards the end. Medium body - on tap the C02 was a little on the light side. Proof, downstairs w/PorterPounder.

Light but hoppy. Grapefruit, floral notes, a nice bitter and dry hops finish. I get this one. I would choose this over a macro brew any day. Easily drinkable, punchy and crisp, enough flavor and hops.

Pours bright yellow slight haze but fairly clear with a white head. Fairly active carbonation. Aroma is amazing..wow, simcoe cat pee type thing going on with a myrad of floral and citrus beauty. Extremely light almost non exsistant malt profile. This is all hops, its incredibly hoppy. Lots tropical Fruit, some citrus, and a bunch of other great hops stuff going on. Love it. Almost to much great hop flavor.

I'm not a big IPA person, but I get the appeal. It's a decent session IPA regardless. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Bottle. Pours a bright gold with a high, smooth, creamy white head. Nose is intense lime, grapefruit, and a touch of cat pee -- its not quite right in the balance. Im not getting any pine or herbal notes at all. Hops on the front of the mouth, but then it opens into this weird processed-American-cheese thing. Makes me wonder if I have a bad bottle; its a sample from the distributor, so I think not, but...finish is long and a little dirty. Im not impressed.

UPDATED: APR 6, 2014 Pours a pale yellow with a white head. Aroma and Taste is citrus, a big blast of grapefruit pine aroma hits your senses but mellows out a bit, there is some grass and pale malt as well, mild bitterness. Palate is a medium body, carbonation is there but mild. Finishes with a bit of floral, grapefruit pine, pale malt and mild bitterness. Not a very bitter brew and although its a session style brew the aroma seemed a bit overwhelming, an ok brew overall.

Bottle from Jims in Mundelein. Pours a very pale yellow/orange with a spongey white head leaving some streaks of lace. Aroma has - HELLO HOPS! Big floral and citrus hops, and then some more of the same for emphasis. Further down in the glass there is some pine and even some biscuity malts which come through. Those are not the lead in this bottle. Taste is of sweet fruits including big pineapple, plus very bitter lemon, orange and grapefruit. Down in the glass, it is more bitter - lemon zest, orange peels. Light to medium bodied and bone dry. Finishes super bitter. Unabashedly hopcentric and quite bitter in focus. Virtually no alcohol noted. Sessionable, certainly, if you are a bitter hop person. RuinTen if they somehow pulled 6% of the ABV out?
Bottle. Great citrus hop nose. Light, clean body, nice hoppy flavors of citrus and grass. A bit simple, but an easy drinking and interesting beer for the weight.
UPDATED: APR 18, 2014 Awesome IPA, on tap at library alehouse in santa monica, good stuff, thanks Eric. Orange hazy pour, white head, smells bitter and piney, taste of citrus, nice.
